item.title: Auditory Haptic
item.description:
Alarms

  • Conspicuous from ambient noise
    15~30dB required

  • Remain within the safe range
    below 85 to 90 dB
    masking 위협때문에 여러 소리를 혼합해서 냄

  • Not disruptive with other signals

  • Informative and distinctive

    1. stereotypic: 어디서 소리가 오는지
    2. pitch physical dimension(pitch(4), duration(4), magnification(4)) <= 4

Non-speech Alarm

  • language independent
    글로벌하게 가고 싶다면

  • Evidence to show they are useful
    fewer mistakes with key click
    video games harder without sound

  • Especially good for transient/background status info

  • use of stereo allow positional information
    비쥬얼로는 3d 표현하기 어려움

Voice Alarm

  • voice is beign accepted as a natural way to interact with devices
  • Able to give more meanings than symbolic alarm
    symbolic alarm은 학습을 해야한다는 단점이 있음
  • Limitations
    1. more confusable with a background sound and communication: 소리가 섞이면 헷갈림
    2. more susceptible to frequency-specific masking
      사람의 voice는 정해진 주파수가 있다.
    3. need to consider the multilingual environment
    4. Sound Transmission Problem

voice recognition

  • Articulation index: pure bottom-up approach
    physical 품질
    0.1: 10% of speech is understood
    0.9: 90% of speech is understood
    1.0: 100% of speech is understood
    0.3: 30% of speech is understood
    0.5: 50% of speech is understood
    0.7: 70% of speech is understood

  • Speech intelligibility measure poor signal quality is compensated by top-down processing
    restricting message set size, redundant carrier sentence

Tactile Perception

  • Touch is complex
  • Only bi-directional communication channel
  • Mechanoreceptor detect skin deformation
  • Tactile acuity is determined by the density of mechanoreceptor
  • Tactile information
    1. feedback by force: 저항감
    2. feedback by vibration:

item.title: 사실주의
item.description:
• 유럽 아방가르드(반사실주의): 환상적인 장면, 다다이즘, 과거회상, 부조리 연극, 상징주의, 표현주의 이 등장
  • 미국은 사실주의 포기 못함
  • 반사실주의와 절충한 수정 사실주의 등장
  • 사실주의보다는 연극성을 강조
  • 반사실주의보다는 환영주의에 덜 의존
  • 잘 짜여진 극(well made) 기법에 덜 의존
  • 내면적 리얼리즘
  • 변화의 원인: 잠재의식 영역 인정

대표작

테네시 윌리엄스 욕망이라는 이름의 전차

item.title: Data Modeling and the Entity-Relationship Model
item.description:
Data and information

  • Data: 사실
  • Information: meaningful context

What is information system?

  • System: a set of components that interact to achieve some purpose or goal

  • Information System: composed of hardware, software, data, procedures, people

SDLC (System Development Life Cycle)

  1. System definitions
  2. Requirements analysis
  3. Component design
  4. Implementation
  5. System maintenance

item.title: Logic and Proofs
item.description:
Proposition

declarative sentence that is either true or false

propositional variable

p, q, r, s, …
ex) p: it is raining

Proposition must be either true or false.
‘x is 10’ is not a proposition.

Logical Operators

(ascending order of precedence)

  • Negation: ¬ NOT
  • Conjunction: ∧ AND
  • Disjunction: ∨ OR
    • Inclusive OR: either is true
    • Exclusive OR: ⊕ either is true, but not both
  • Implication: -> if then it is not real-world’s causual relationship. just depend on p and q's value
    ex) If I am elected, then I will lower taxes.
    if politician is elected but not lower taxes, implication is false.
    but politician is not elected, no matter what, implication is true.
  • Biconditional: <-> if and only if

Truth Table

p q ¬p p∧q p∨q p->q p<->q
T T F T T T T
T F F F T F F
F T T F T T F
F F T F F T T

Different Ways of Expressing Implication

  • if p, then q
  • if p, q
  • q unless ¬ p
  • q if p
  • q whenever p
  • q follows from p
  • p implies q
  • p only if q
  • q when p
  • p is sufficient for q
  • q is necessary for p
  • a necessary condition for p is q
  • a sufficient condition for q is p

Different Ways of Expressing Biconditional

  • p is necessary and sufficient for q
  • if p then q, and conversely
  • p iff q.
  • p exactly when q.

if you confuse

Converse, Contrapositive, Inverse

If implication is p->q

  • Converse: q->p
  • Inverse: ¬p -> ¬q
  • Contrapositive: ¬q -> ¬p

Logical Equivalence

  • tautology: always true
  • contradiction: always false
  • contingency: neither tautology nor contradiction
  • logical equivalence: ≡ two propositions are always true or false together

Laws of Logic

  • Identity Laws
    • P ∧ T ≡ P
    • P ∨ F ≡ P
  • Domination Laws
    • P ∨ T ≡ T
    • P ∧ F ≡ F
  • Idempotent Laws
    • P ∨ P ≡ P
    • P ∧ P ≡ P
  • Double Negation Laws
    • ¬(¬P) ≡ P
  • Absorption Laws
    • P ∨ (P ∧ Q) ≡ P
    • P ∧ (P ∨ Q) ≡ P
  • Negation Laws
    • P ∨ ¬P ≡ T
    • P ∧ ¬P ≡ F
  • Commutative Laws
    • P ∨ Q ≡ Q ∨ P
    • P ∧ Q ≡ Q ∧ P
  • Associative Laws
    • (P ∨ Q) ∨ R ≡ P ∨ (Q ∨ R)
    • (P ∧ Q) ∧ R ≡ P ∧ (Q ∧ R)
  • Distributive Laws
    • P ∨ (Q ∧ R) ≡ (P ∨ Q) ∧ (P ∨ R)
    • P ∧ (Q ∨ R) ≡ (P ∧ Q) ∨ (P ∧ R)
  • De Morgan's Laws
    • ¬(P ∧ Q) ≡ ¬P ∨ ¬Q
    • ¬(P ∨ Q) ≡ ¬P ∧ ¬Q

A Few More Equivalences

  • p -> q ≡ ¬p ∨ q
  • p -> q ≡ ¬q -> ¬p
  • p ∨ q ≡ ¬p -> q
  • p ∧ q ≡ ¬(p -> ¬q)
  • (p -> q) ∧ (p -> r) ≡ p -> (q ∧ r)
  • (p -> r) ∧ (q -> r) ≡ (p ∨ q) -> r
  • (p -> q) ∨ (p -> r) ≡ p -> (q ∨ r)
  • (p -> r) ∨ (q -> r) ≡ (p ∧ q) -> r
  • p <-> q ≡ (p -> q) ∧ (q -> p)
  • p <-> q ≡ ¬p <-> ¬q
  • p <-> q ≡ (p ∧ q) ∨ (¬p ∧ ¬q)
  • ¬(p <-> q) ≡ p <-> ¬q

Predicates and Quantifiers

  • predicate: a sentence that contains a finite number of variables and becomes a proposition when specific values are substituted for the variables
  • quantifiers
    • ∀: for all,
    • ∃: there exists
    • ∃!: there exists unique
    • ¬∀ ≡ ∃, ¬∃ ≡ ∀

Rules of Inference

Modus Ponens

p -> q
p
______
∴ q

Modus Tollens

p -> q
¬q
______
∴ ¬p

Hypothetical Syllogism

p -> q
q -> r
______
∴ p -> r

Disjunctive Syllogism

p ∨ q
¬p
______
∴ q

Addition

p
______
∴ p ∨ q

Simplification

p ∧ q
______
∴ q

Conjunction

p
q
______
∴ p ∧ q

Resolution

¬p ∨ r
p ∨ q
______
∴ q ∨ r

Universal instantiation (UI)

∀xp(x)
______
∴ p(c) c is an arbitrary constant in the domain of x

Universal generalization (UG)

p(c) for an arbitrary c
______
∴ ∀xp(x)

Existential instantiation (EI)

∃xp(x)
______
∴ p(c) for some c

Existential generalization (EG)

p(c) for some element c
______
∴ ∃xp(x)

Methods of Proofs

  • direct proof
    p -> q 형태로 치환 후, p가 참이라 가정
    trivial proof: q가 true인걸 알 경우
    vacuous proof: p가 false인걸 알 경우

  • proof by contraposition
    ¬q -> ¬p 형태로 치환 후, ¬q가 참이라 가정

  • proof by contradiction

    • one proposition: ¬p가 참이라 가정 후, contradiction(always false)를 찾음
    • p -> q: p ∧ ¬q가 참이라 가정 후, contradiction을 찾음

  • proof by cases
    도메인의 모든 경우를 나누어서 증명

  • proof of Existence
    ∃xP(x)를 증명

proof

  • theorem: 증명된 명제
  • lemma: 보조정리
  • corollary: 정리의 결과로 얻어지는 명제
  • conjecture: 증명되지 않은 명제

item.title: 진도 나갈거 예상
item.description:
1. Number theory and cryptography
  • Number Theory: Properties of integers, divisibility, prime numbers, and modular arithmetic.
  • Cryptography: Techniques for secure communication, including encryption and decryption methods.
  1. Induction and recursion
  • Mathematical Induction: Proof technique used to prove statements about natural numbers.
  • Recursion: Defining functions or sequences where the next term is derived from previous terms.
  1. Counting
  • Combinatorics: Study of counting, arrangement, and combination of objects.
  • Permutations and Combinations: Methods to count arrangements and selections.
  1. Graphs
  • Graph Theory: Study of graphs, which are mathematical structures used to model pairwise relations between objects.
  • Applications: Network analysis, shortest path problems, and graph coloring.

item.title: 가부키
item.description:
가부키 무대 구조

  • 가(노래) + 부(춤) + 키(연극)의 합성어
  • 하나미치(꽃길)

가부키의 기원

  • 1603년 사찰 무희 오쿠니에서 시작
  • 성적으로 병질되면서 1653년부터는 성인 남성만 출연 가능하게 됨
  • 근데 남자가 여자연기를 하는게 예술적이라고 생각함.
  • 막과 하나미치의 발명으로 1688년 경에 연극으로서 비약함
    => 야외극에서 실내극으로 변화

무대 미학

  • 하나미치로 관객과 배우가 가까워짐
  • 수직형 연극: 배우가 관객을 바라보며 연기함
  • 스펙터클의 창조: 무대에 호화로운 장치가 많다. (세리, 슷폰)
    간도가에시: 무대를 뒤로 90도로 눕혀서 장면 전환
    야타이 구즈시: 무대가 무너짐
    추노리: 와이어 연기
  • 서민예술, 쾌락의 예술

item.title: Algorithm
item.description:
Algorithms

algorithm: finite sequence of precise instructions for performing a computation or for solving a problem.

Pseudo code

완전히 정해진 문법은 없는듯. 이산수학에서 사용하는 형태는 다음과 같다.

Properties of Algorithms

  • Input
  • Output: solution to the problem
  • Definiteness. The steps of an algorithm must be defined precisely.
  • Correctness
  • Finiteness: 무한루프 돌면 안된다.
  • Effectiveness
  • Generality

Example of Algorithms

  • 유한한 정수 집단에서 가장 큰 수 찾기
  • 검색 알고리즘
    • 선형 검색
    • 이진 검색
  • 정렬
    • 버블 정렬
    • 선택 정렬
  • 그리디 알고리즘

The Growth of Functions

Big-O Notation

  • if there exists a constant and such that for all
  • if
  • 당연히 여러개일 수 있다.

Big-Ω Notation

Big-θ Notation

Complexity of Algorithms

combination of funciton

if and , then

ordering functions by order of growth

big-omega

lowerbound: if there exists a constant and such that for all

big-theta

if and

complexity

item.title: 삼각함수 정리
삼각함수 정리
item.description:
용어정리

  • 양의 방향: 시초선에서 시작하여 시계방향
  • 음의 방향: 시초선에서 시작하여 반시계방향
  • 동경: 각도 를 나타내는 선분

(직각)삼각비

  • 세 변의 길이의 비율.
  • 높이와 밑변은 상대적.

특수각

삼각비 30 45 60
1

호도법

  • 호도법: 각도를 호의 길이로 나타내는 방법.

  • π = 180°

  • θ = 반지름의 길이가 1인 원과 각도가 θ인 동경의 접점의 x좌표

  • θ = 반지름의 길이가 1인 원과 각도가 θ인 동경의 접점의 y좌표

  • θ = 동경의 기울기

item.title: SQL
item.description:
SQL is not programming language but a data sublanguage

DDL (Data Definition Language)

  1. CREATE (database, tables, views, indexes)
  2. ALTER: add, modify, drop columns / constraints
  3. DROP (database, tables, views, indexes)
  4. TRUNCATE (delete all rows)
CREATE TABLE student (
    id INT NOT NULL,
    CourseID INT NOT NULL,
    Name VARCHAR(100),
    Age INT,
    CONSTRAINT STUDENT_PK PRIMARY KEY (id),
    CONSTRAINT COURSE_FK FOREIGN KEY (CourseID) REFERENCES Course(CourseID) ON UPDATE CASACADE
);
ALTER TABLE student ADD COLUMN major VARCHAR(100);
ALTER TABLE student ADD CONSTRAINT STUDENT_FK FOREIGN KEY (CourseID) REFERENCES Course(CourseID) ON DELETE CASCADE;
DROP TABLE student;
TRUNCATE TABLE student;

DML (Data Manipulation Language)

INSERT INTO student VALUES (1, 'Alice', 20);
UPDATE student SET age = 21 WHERE id = 1;
DELETE FROM student WHERE id = 1;

DQL (Data Query Language)

A query create temporarily a new table.
this allows a query to create a new relation and feed information to another query as a subquery

SELECT * FROM student;
SELECT name 
FROM student 
WHERE age > 20;
SELECT DISTINCT name FROM student;
